qas.question: According to Mendelian inheritance, what is part of the cause of variations in an organism's phenotype?
What sort of characteristics are described by an organism's phenotype?
What specifies a particular trait with a different sequence of alleles?
How many alleles do most eukaryotic organisms have for each trait?

context: According to Mendelian inheritance, variations in an organism's phenotype (<a1_0>observable physical and behavioral characteristics<a1_0/>) are due in part to <a0_0>variations in its genotype<a0_0/> (<a2_0>particular set of genes<a2_0/>). <a3_0>Each gene<a3_0/> specifies a particular trait with different sequence of a gene (alleles) giving rise to different phenotypes. Most eukaryotic organisms (such as the pea plants Mendel worked on) have <a4_0>two alleles for each trait<a4_0/>, one inherited from each parent.:20
